title: ChIP-SICAP
article_citation: Rafiee M, Sigismondo G, Kalxdorf M, Förster L, Brügger B, Béthune J, Krijgsveld J, Protease‐resistant streptavidin for interaction proteomics. Molecular Systems Biology 16(5). doi: 10.15252/msb.20199370

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Detach the cells by Accutase. Accutase doesn’t lyse cells, so it is more suitable for single cell preparation. After detaching the cells, make sure that they are single cell by pipetting in the medium.

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Count the cells.

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Resuspend the cells in formaldehyde 1.5% in PBS. Roughly for every 10 million mammalian cells, add 10ml formaldehyde 1.5%. Pipette up and down to disrupt the cell pellet completely.

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Rotate occasionally, and keep it 15min at room temperature.

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Add Glycine 1M to stop the crosslinking, so the final concentration will be 130mM (1.5ml Glycine for every 10ml of formaldehyde).

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Rotate occasionally 5min at room temperature.

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Spin the cells at 2000RPM, 2min. Discard the supernatant (SN).

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Resuspend the cells with PBS-T, equal volume to the formaldehyde volume that you'd used in step 4

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Spin the cells at 2000RPM, 2min, and discard the SN.

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Resuspend the cells in some PBS-T
Inside a fume hood, remove the medium, and pour 10ml of formaldehyde 1.5% in a 10cm dish.
·If you estimate there are more than 10 million cells, you may pour 20ml of formaldehyde
Wait 15min, and rotate the plate gently.
Add Glycine to the final concentration of 130mM
Wait 5min, and rotate the plate gently.
In the meantime, mix LB3 with 1x Complete protease inhibitor. For each 10cm plate you may need 10ml of LB3
Discard the liquid, and pour 10ml of PBS
Rotate the plate gently, and gently discard the liquid
Repeat the last two steps once again.
Pour 3ml of LB3+Complete on the plate.
·LB3 allows to collect the cells more efficiently. While, using PBS you will lose quite some cells.
10.Scrap the cells with LB3, and collect them in one side of the plate. Then collect them and pour them in a Falcone tube (15 or 50ml depending on the volume)
11.Repeat the last two steps, twice.
12.Spin the cells at 2000RPM for 2 min, and discard the SN
13.Resuspend the cells in LB3+Complete
14.Repeat the last two steps once again.
15.To measure the protein concentration, take 5ul of the cells, pour it in a PCR tube and add 1ul of Benzonase
16.Incubate at 37°C for 30min
17.Add 30ul of SDS wash buffer, and incubate at 95°C for 5 min
18.Measure the protein concentration by a BCA kit

·The standards of the BCA should be treated the same. Namely, mix 5ul of the standards with 30ul of the SDS wash buffer, and incubate them at 95°C for 5min. Then 25ul of each sample/standard should be loaded on a 96w plate to measure the protein concentrations by the BCA reagents. A 2mg/ml standard and blank standard would be enough to compare the protein concentrations of the samples.
19.Calculate the protein concentrationsAdjust the protein concentration with LB3+compele, aliquot the samples

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: Count the cells, and Aliqoute them. e.g. every 24 millions in a 15-ml tube

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description:
Spin the cells at 2000 RPM 2min, and discard the SN. Freeze the cells in liquid nitrogen
Pause point: You may freeze the cells in -80°C for months.

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Wait 15min, and rotate the plate gently.

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Add Glycine to the final concentration of 130mM

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Rotate the plate gently, and wait 5min.

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Discard the liquid, gently pour 10ml of PBS on the cells, rotate, and discard it

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Repeat the last step once again.

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description:
Pour 3ml of PBS-T (Tween 0.1%) on the plate.
Triton allows to collect the cells more efficiently. While, using PBS you will lose quite some cells.
Adding Complete protease inhibitor is optional. Apparantely, endogenous proteases are inactivated by formaldehyde.

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Scrap the cells with a cell lifter, and collect them in one side of the plate. Then transfer them by a pipet to a tube (e.g. 15ml or 50ml depending on the number of the plates)

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Repeat the last two steps, once again for each plate.

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Spin the cells at 2000RPM for 2 min, and discard the supernatant

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Resuspend the cells in PBS-T, and aliqoute the them if you wish

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Spin the cells at 2000RPM 2 min, and discard the supernatant

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description:
Freeze the cells in liquid nitrogen, and keep them in -80 ºC
Pause point: You may freeze the cells in -80°C for months.

source.title: Part #1-B: crosslinking the cells in a plate, and then harvesting them

source.description: Inside a fume hood, remove the medium, and pour 10ml of formaldehyde 1.5% in a 10cm dish.

source.title: Part #1-A: detach and crosslink the cells

source.description: 1-Resuspend

source.description: million cells in 1ml of LB3+Complete and vortex, and divide it into 2x 1.5ml tubes specifically designed for Bioruptor pico

source.description: ·

source.description: 2-Keep on ice for 5min

source.title: Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin

source.description: 3-Spin 2000g, 2min

source.description: 4-Discard the supernatant.

source.title: Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin

source.title: Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin

source.description: 7-Sonicating conditions depends on the cell lines. Bioruptor Pico is faster, however, Covaris is more precise and reproducible. You may start with Bioruptor Pico, and apply 7 cycles ON and OFF (30’’-30’’).

source.title: Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin

source.description: ·If you used approach #2 for crosslinking, please thaw the cell lysates, and transfer 300ul to the sonication tubes. This should be about 1mg proteins as one replicate.

source.description: ·Adding SDS to the final concentration of 0.1% improves the efficiency of sonication. However, some antibodies are sensitive to it.

source.title: Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin
Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin

source.description: 8-After the sonication spin the sonication tubes 10min at 12000g

source.title: Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin

source.description: 9-Collect the supernatant, and transfer it into a new 2ml epi-tube.

source.title: Part #2: Sonicating the cells and shearing chromatin

source.description: 0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'>You may take 5ul of the samples, to check the sheared chromatin. Boil and clean up DNA using QIAgen PCR purification kit. Run the DNA on an agarose gel. The smear should be <1kb. Unlike ChIP-seq that needs short fragments, ChIP-SICAP works with larger fragments. You may optimize the sonication. Alternatively, you may add a restriction enzyme in step 24 to cut the chromatin to smaller fragments.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description:
Resuspend the cells in 0.9ml Tris-Cl 10mM. Then add 100ul Tritone X100 10%(v/v). Leave the cells on ice for 5 min
Optional: You may also add Complete protease inhibitor.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Spin the cells 2min at 2000RPM. Discard the supernatant.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Resuspend the cells in 1ml LB3 buffer. Spin the cells 2min at 2000RPM. Discard the supernatant.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Repeat Step 31, twice again.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description:
Resuspend the cells in LB3 buffer.
  • Resuspend every 8 million cells in 250ul LB3 buffer, and-so-forth.
  • One 10cm dish of confluent mES cells is about 20 million cells. Therefore, you may resuspend the cells in 750ul LB3 buffer.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description:
Sonicating conditions depends on the cell lines. For mES cells using Bioruptor Pico, you may apply 7 cycles ON and OFF (30’’-30’’).
  • Bioruptor Pico is faster, however, Covaris is more precise and reproducible.
  • Adding SDS to the final concentration of 0.1% improves the efficiency of sonication. However, some antibodies are sensitive to it. You may add 0.1% sodium deoxycholate or 0.1% Sarkosyl.
  • Too many cycles of sonication blast the proteins from chromatin.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: After the sonication spin the sonication tubes 10min at 12000g

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Collect the supernatant, and transfer it into a 2ml epi-tube or a 15ml tube. You may pool the sheared chromatin obtained from one replicate.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Measure the protein concentration using a BCA protein assay kit.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Aliqoute the resuspended cells into Biorupotor Pico 1.5ml special tubes.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Pour up to 1 mg protein (chromatin) in a 2-ml epi-tube as one replicate.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description:
Add Triton X100 from a 10% (v/v) stock to make the final conc. 1%
Pause point: You may freeze the samples in -80°C for weeks.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description:
Put the tubes on the magnet, after 1min remove the liquid, and take the tubes off the magnet. Immidiately pour 1000ul of Tris-HCl 10mM pH 7.5 (without EDTA) on the beads.
  • Process the tubes one by one. Never allow the beads to dry.
  • Here the idea is to remove the inhibitors of the enzymatic reactions (e.g. EDTA). Stringent washes come later.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Resuspend the beads by rotating end to end, and transfer them to a new 2ml epi-tube.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Keep 1%, as the input control for ChIP-qPCR/seq

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Add proper amounts of your antibody to the samples.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Agitate at 800RPM overnight in a Thermomixer (eppendorf) at 4°C or cold room

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: After the overnight incubation, spin the samples at 12000g for 10min at 4°C

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description:
Collect 95% of the liquid and transfer it into a new 2-ml epi-tube
  • You may not see the pellet easily, however, sometimes there is a transparent precipitation
  • A 2-ml epi-tube is necessary for efficient agitation in the next steps.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Adjust the volume to 1ml by adding IP buffer.

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: For each tube, you will need to prepare 40ul of ProteinA or ProteinG Dynabeads (depending on the antibody).

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Add 40ul magnetic Dynabeads to each tube

source.title: Part #2: Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

source.description: Rotate the samples 2-4 hours at 4°C (cold room) on a rotating wheel.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Resuspend the beads in 200ul of NEB Cutsmart buffer 1x. Don’t pipet the beads. Gently swirl the tube to resuspend the beads.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description:
Optional: If you wish to improve the efficiency of DNA end-labeling you may perform the folloing step. Although TdT adds nucleotides to 3’- and 5’-overhangs and blunt ends, Klenow 3’exo- adds biotinylated dATP to only 5’overhangs or blunt ends. Combination of these two enzymes improves DNA end-labelling about 10-20%. In addition, T4 PNK removes 3'-phosphates, and prepares the 3'-OH ends for TdT and Klenow.
Prepare the following mixture for each tube. You may prepare a master mix for all the tubes:
  • Cutsmart buffer 10x 10 ul
  • Klenow 3’exo- 2 ul
  • dBTP (C+G+T) 10mM 1 ul
  • Biotin-dATP 1mM 10 ul
  • T4 PNK 1ul
Fill up to 100ul with H2O
Note: dBTP means al nucleotides except dATP.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Put the samples one by one on the magnet, remove the liquid, and take the tubes off the magnet. Pour the mixture prepared in the previous step on the beads. Gently swirl the beads to resuspend the beads.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Incubate at 37°C in a thermomixer with agitation at 700 RPM for 30 min.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Put the samples one by one on the magnet, after 1min remove the liquid, and take the tubes off the magnet. Resuspend the beads in 100ul of TdT buffer 1x.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Put the samples one by one on the magnet, remove the liquid, and take the tubes off the magnet. Resuspend the beads in the mixture prepared in step 55. Gently swirl the beads to resuspend the beads.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description:
To each tube add :
  • TdT 4ul
  • Optional: RNase A 1ul
TdT is a quite specific enzyme for DNA labelling, as evident by TUNEL assay. Adding RNase A reassures specific DNA labelling.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Incubate at 37°C in a thermomixer with agitation at 800 RPM for 30min.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Wash the beads 4 times with 1ml ice-cold IP buffer at room temp.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Remove the last IP wash buffer

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Resuspend the beads in 100ul, SDS 7.5% + DTT 200mM, and vortex vigorously

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Incubate 15min at 37°C in a thermomixer, with 1000 RPM

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Put the samples on the magnet, collect the liquid, and discard the beads

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description:
Prepare the following mixture for each tube. You may prepare a master mix for all tubes:
  • TdT buffer (including CoCl2) 20ul
  • Biotin-dCTP 5ul
  • Biotin-ddUTP 5ul
  • Fill up to 95ul with H2O
Note: Biotin-dCTP was used to reduce the cost. You may use 10ul of biotin-ddUTP.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Dilute the liquid with 1000ul IP buffer

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Add 70ul of Streptavidin magnetic beads to each tube. Rotate the tubes for 30-60min at room temptrature.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Put the tubes on the magnet after 2 min discard the solution.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description:
Wash the beads 3 times by SDS wash buffer
  • Each washing consists of resuspending the beads in the washing solution by vortexing, briefly spinning, and putting on the magnet for 2 min to remove the solution
  • After the second wash, normally you should be able to see the beads are dispersed, except the negative control.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Wash with BW2x buffer, once

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Wash the beads with Iso-propanol wash buffer, once

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Wash the beads with acetonitrile wash buffer, twice

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Resuspend the beads in 80ul acetonitrile wash buffer, and transfer it into a PCR tubes.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Put the tubes on the magnet, and remove the wash buffer.

source.title: Part #3: Selective isolation of Chromatin-Asscotiated Proteins (SICAP)

source.description: Spin the tubes briefly, and remove the residues of the wash buffer

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description:
Resuspend the beads in 20ul Ambic 50mM + 10mM DTT (or TEAB 50mM for dimethylation or TMT labelling)
Note: freshly prepared Ambic should be used.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Incubate the beads at 50°C for 15min

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description:
Chill the beads, and add 2ul of IAA 0.4M
IAA: Iodoacetimide

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Vortex, and keep the tubes in a drawer for 15-30min

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Add 0.5ul of DTT 1M to neutralize IAA

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Add 300ng of LysC (3ul of 100ng/ul), vortex, and spin briefly

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Incubate overnight at 37 °C (12-16h)

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Remove the beads, and transfer the liquid into new PCR tubes.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Heat the samples (without the beads) at 95 °C for 5min to reverse the formaldehyde crosslinking

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Chill the samples briefly

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Add 100ng of Trypsin (1ul of 100ng/ul)

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Incubate at 37°C for 8h.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Add 1ul TFA 10% to the digested samples to acidify the pH

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Pour 50ul of Acetonitrile 80% + formic acid 0.1% in a glass insert (tubes for auto-sampler)

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Set a P20 on 20ul, and pick up a zip-tip

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Pipete 20ul Acetonitrile 100%, and discard the liquid. Repeat once again.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Equilibrate the zip-tip by pipetting 20ul TFA 0.1%, and discard the liquid. Repeat twice again.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Pipet one sample 10 times. Do not generate bubbles.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Wash the zip-tip by pipetting 20ul TFA 0.1%, and discard the liquid. Repeat once again.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Elute the peptides by pipetting Acetonitrile 80% + formic acid 0.1% in the glass insert

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Dry out the eluent in an appropriate speed vac.

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Reconstitute the peptides in 8ul DMSO 2% + formic acid 0.1%

source.title: Part #4: Digesting proteins and sample preparation for mass spectrometry

source.description: Inject 7 out of 8 ul of the samples to the mass spec

source.title: Appendix #2: Clean up the DNA by Ampure XP beads

source.description: Spin the samples, and put them on a magnetic rack to separate the beads.

source.title: Appendix #2: Clean up the DNA by Ampure XP beads

source.title: Appendix #2: Clean up the DNA by Ampure XP beads

source.description: Spin the samples, and put them on a magnetic rack to separate the beads.

source.title: Appendix #2: Clean up the DNA by Ampure XP beads

source.description: Collect the samples, and transfer them to new tubes. The samples can be used for qPCR or library preparation.

source.description: Wash the beads with 10ml PBS-T

source.title: Appendix #1: Modification of streptavidin beads to avoid streptavidin contamination

source.description: Put the tube on the magnet, wait 5min and then discard the liquid

source.description: Resuspend the beads in 5mL PBS-T

source.title: Appendix #1: Modification of streptavidin beads to avoid streptavidin contamination

source.description: 14-Keep the beads in the fridge. The beads are stable at +4⁰C for months

description: Chromatin immunoprecipitation combined with mass spectrometry (ChIP-MS) suffers from unexpected proteins that bind to chromatin during the cell lysis and immunoprecipitation (IP). The so-called hitchhikers of chromatin are hardly washed away by gentle washing steps applied to a normal IP protocol. We employed DNA end-labeling by Terminal Transferase (TdT) to purify proteins specifically bound to chromatin. Using this double purification strategy, chromatin fragments are released from IP beads, and re-captured by streptavidin beads. Thus, we can apply stringent conditions to remove the hitchhikers of chromatin, and to identify authentic proteins co-localized with the protein of interest. We call this protocol Selective Isolation of Chromatin-Associated Proteins (SICAP). So far, ChIP-SICAP was successfully applied to different cell lines such mouse ES cells, mouse fibroblast cells, HEK 293T, HeLa, U2OS as well as mouse and human tissues. Here, we share the most updated version of our protocol. If you have any questions please feel free to email us.
